Title: Drought, low flows on Russian River closed Veteran's Memorial Beach in Healdsburg, California for four years
Description:
Healdsburg's Veterans Memorial Beach on the Russian River has reopened after drought and the COVID pandemic led the Sonoma County Regional Parks to postpone opening the beach for swimming for the past four years.
KPIX-TV CBS 5 San Francisco (Calif.), June 29, 2023

Mountain View Voice (Calif.), May 25, 2023

Title: Drought contributed to losses to water, wastewater and electric funds in Healdsburg, California
Description:
Water and wastewater revenues in Healdsburg were sharply reduced this year, due to mandatory reductions in water use to conserve water. The financial shortfall led the city to freeze two vacant Utility and Public Works positions and defer infrastructure maintenance. As of March 31, the end of the third quarter, both funds were behind in revenue, down 10% to date, for a combined $1.09 million loss over projections through that period. To compensate for the shortfalls, spending from the water fund was cut by about $251,000, while spending from the wastewater fund was reduced by about $9,600 for fiscal year 2023-24. Maintenance will be delayed on water fountains, distribution pipes and pumps. 
Healdsburg operates its own electric utility, which also suffered a shortfall. The electric fund was down by 6% to $9.01 million through the third quarter. 
Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), May 22, 2023

Title: Water-shortage mandate ended in Healdsburg, California
Description:
Healdsburg residents were to reduce their water use by 20% until the Healdsburg City Council lifted the edict at the meeting on April 3, 2023. The 6% water-shortage surcharge was also lifted. Any remaining state water-usage restrictions will remain in effect until December, according to the California State Water Board.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 10, 2023

Title: Cal Water returned to Stage 1 restrictions; Bakersfield, California at Stage 2
Description:
Cal Water has rescinded Stage 2 of its water shortage contingency plan and was at Stage 1. Stage 2 restrictions began in December 2021. 
Bakersfield’s Domestic Water System, however, remained at Stage 2 of its drought mitigation plan as they rely on groundwater instead of surface water. Between October 2022 and March 2023, water customers reduced their use by 16.5% compared to the same time frame three years ago.
BakersfieldNow (Calif.), May 11, 2023

Title: Proposed water rate hike for Marin Municipal Water District in California could help recover financial reserves
Description:
Marin Municipal Water District is considering a proposed rate hike which would be used to pay for new water supply projects over the next two years. The repair of aging facilities and recovering financial reserves lost during the drought. The median residential customer would see their bimonthly bill increase by 20%. 
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), May 7, 2023

Title: Full allocation for California's State Water Project
Description:
The fifth snow survey of the season at Phillips Station revealed a snow depth of 59 inches and a snow water equivalent of 30 inches, which is 241 percent of average for May 1. Electronic readings from the 130 snow sensors across California indicate a statewide snow water equivalent of 49.2 inches, or 254% of average for the date. Overall, the statewide snowpack melted more slowly than usual during April as temperatures were below average early in the month, and there was more cloud cover. Temperatures increased in the latter part of April. 
California Department of Water Resources (Sacramento), May 1, 2023

The Department of Water Resources announced that State Water Project deliveries are expected to be 100% of requested water supplies for the first time since 2006. The March estimate was 75% of requested supplies. Water from the SWP is delivered to 29 public water agencies serving 27 million Californians and 750,000 acres of farmland. 
California Department of Water Resources (Sacramento), April 20, 2023

The State Water Project will deliver 75% of requested supplies as winter storms brought tremendous amounts of snow this winter.
Los Angeles Times, March 24, 2023

The California Department of Water Resources announced an expected water allocation of 35% from the State Water Project, up from 30% in January. 
The Associated Press (New York), Feb 22, 2023

The series of storms that brought heavy rain and snow to California have partially filled reservoirs, allowing the State Water Project to offer 30% of requested water supplies to 29 public water agencies that serve 27 million Californians. The initial allocation in December was just 5%.
California typically receives half its rain and snow by the end of January. Water managers will reassess conditions monthly during the winter and spring, and also consider snowpack data and runoff forecasts from February on.
California Department of Water Resources (Sacramento)
Jan 26, 2023

The Department of Water Resources announced an initial State Water Project allocation of 5 percent of requested supplies for 2023. The SWP provides water to 29 public water agencies that serve 27 million Californians. Water allocations are frequently low early in the wet season due to uncertainty in hydrologic forecasting. In addition, the expectation is for a fourth dry year and continued drought in California. Lake Oroville, the largest reservoir in the State Water Project system, is just 55% of average for this time of year. Oroville ended Water Year 2022 at about 400,000 acre-feet higher than the previous year. 
For the 2022 Water Year, the initial allocation was 0% on Dec. 1, 2021, with limited water designated only for any unmet human health and safety needs. Last year’s final allocation was 5 percent plus unmet health and safety needs. Four of the 29 State Water Contractors ultimately requested and received additional health and safety water supply.
California Department of Water Resources (Sacramento, Calif.), Dec 1, 2022

Title: Drought emergency for Zone 7 water customers in Alameda County, California
Description:
The Zone 7 Water Agency ended its drought emergency, which mandated 15% reduction in water use, the week of April 17, 2023. The Dublin San Ramon Services District also declared an end to the emergency order and restored water rates to normal.  DSRSD serves Dublin and Dougherty Valley.
Livermore Independent (Calif.), April 23, 2023

Zone 7 Water Agency declared a drought emergency in September, requiring a savings of 15% from all water service providers in Livermore, Pleasanton and the Dublin San Ramon Services District. The drought emergency remains in effect, despite recent rainfall.
PleasantonWeekly.com (Calif.), Nov 21, 2021

The 15% water conservation mandate and drought-emergency status were still in effect for the Tri-Valley, despite recent rain. 
Livermore Independent (Calif.), Oct 27, 2021

Drought and low water storage led the Zone 7 Water Agency Board of Directors to unanimously declare a drought emergency and mandate 15% water use reduction for all Zone 7 retailers.  July water savings was about 7%, compared to July 2020, so action is needed immediately to ensure adequate supplies in 2022.  A Stage 2 Shortage Emergency and local drought emergency resolution were also approved at the Sept. 1 special board meeting.
Zone 7 serves customers in the cities of Livermore and Pleasanton, Dublin-San Ramon Services District and the California Water Service Company.
DanvilleSan Ramon (Calif.), Sept 2, 2021

Title: Water restrictions for Metropolitan Water District of Southern California
Description:
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California announced that it would no longer mandate emergency restrictions on water use for nearly 7 million people after winter storms eased shortage conditions that severely limited the availability of state water supplies.
KTLA 5 (Los Angeles, Calif.), March 15, 2023

Harsher water restrictions took effect on June 1 for more than 6 million customers of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California who were asked to curb water use by 35%. The below normal winter snowfall did not refill reservoirs much, leaving the State Water Project offering just 5% of normal allotments. Water users in parts of Los Angeles, Ventura and San Bernardino counties are dependent on water from the SWP and especially need to conserve 35%. 
Los Angeles Times (Calif.), June 1, 2022

The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California adopted water restrictions to reduce water demand. Water districts are offered a choice for conserving water: water outdoors just one day a week or water usage must be kept below some monthly allocation limit. The restrictions affect the district’s six million customers in Los Angeles, Ventura and San Bernardino counties that depend on water from the State Water Project and do not take effect until June 1. 
Local water districts must determine how to communicate requirements to customers and enforce the restrictions. 
Los Angeles Times (Calif.), April 26, 2022

The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California has half of the water that it needs to serve customers in parts of Los Angeles, Ventura and San Bernardino counties, according to Rebecca Kimitch, program manager for MWD. Those customers have been asked to limit outdoor watering to one day per week. 
CNN (Atlanta, Ga.), April 27, 2022

Title: Bobcats hunting, killing small dogs on military bases in California’s High Desert
Description:
Bobcats have been hunting and killing small dogs in backyards at Fort Irwin and at other military bases in California’s High Desert over the past four months. The base has secured a “depredation permit” to capture or kill the wild lynx. A fatal bobcat attack on Feb. 4 was the fifth known case since Oct. 5 of a bobcat or multiple bobcats attacking small, unsupervised dogs weighing less than 30 pounds. 
This is an “extremely rare and unusual” change in bobcat behavior, with no such attacks being reported in recent years. Fort Irwin officials theorize that the attacks may be related to drought limiting the bobcat’s natural prey, such as squirrels and kangaroo rats.

Title: Drought contributed to the deaths of 36.3 million trees in California in 2022
Description:
Tree mortality in California rose to about 36.3 million trees in 2022, due to drought, insects and disease, per the U.S. Forest Service. In 2021, 9.5 million trees died. From mid-July to early October, researchers surveyed almost 40 million acres of federal, state and private land. They found dead trees spread across 2.6 million acres.
The biggest increase in tree mortality was seen in Douglas fir trees. Three million dead Douglas firs were observed, an increase of 1,650%, counted across 190,000 acres, mostly in the central Sierra Nevada Range. 
There were 12 million dead white fir trees, an increase of 691%, across 1.5 million acres, and 15 million dead red firs, an increase of 242%, across 890,000 acres. The dead trees were clustered mainly around the Northern California city of Redding, also in the Shasta-Trinity National Forest and surrounding areas.
Other years with high tree mortality rates were 2016 with nearly 62 million dead trees, 2017 with 27 million trees and 2019 with 15 million dead trees. 
The main cause of the tree mortality is drought, as about 80% of the state endured severe drought since the start of 2022, per the U.S. Drought Monitor. 
Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Feb. 7, 2023

Title: Years of drought affecting California Christmas tree farms
Description:
Just one Christmas tree farm in Calaveras County was open for business this season, selling the big trees that the area is known for as warm temperatures, drought and wildfires took a toll on other area tree farms. Rain and snowfall used to provide all of the moisture that newly planted trees needed, but these days far fewer seedlings survive on precipitation alone. 
The dearth of rain has made it much harder for trees to grow, especially white fir and silvertip fir trees, which usually grow up to 1 foot per year but were now growing just 2 to 3 inches, according to a grower.  He also noted that the dry trees cannot produce pitch, or sap that is used to repel pests.

Title: Record low number of winter-run Chinook salmon fry in California's Sacramento River
Description:
A record low number of endangered winter-run Chinook salmon fry migrated down the Sacramento River this year, according to preliminary data collected by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service at Red Bluff Diversion Dam. An estimated 158,764 fry, or baby salmon, have made it from below Keswick Dam to Red Bluff this year, compared to an average of 1.3 million winter Chinook salmon. This is the second straight year that such low numbers of Chinooks were reported. 
In 2021, an estimated 557,652 winter Chinook swam down the river to Red Bluff. Conditions were very difficult that year as the water was low and warm due to water being diverted to irrigators, resulting in massive fry mortality. 
The low numbers this year were due to fewer adult Chinooks arriving to spawn in the river, compared to 2021, and a thiamine deficiency from a diet high in anchovies.
The hatchery staff processed 16 million eggs altogether with a goal of producing 7.5 million salmon smolts, including the 1.5 million additional fish allocated for the drought.
Stockton Record (Calif.), Dec 6, 2022

Description:

Title: More than 1,200 dry wells in California
Description:
More than 1,200 wells have run dry in California this year, a nearly 50% increase over the same time frame last year, according to the California Department of Water Resources. In comparison, fewer than 100 dry wells were reported annually in 2018, 2019 and 2020.
The groundwater crisis is worst in the San Joaquin Valley, California’s prime agricultural land. Farmers pump more groundwater because they were not getting water, or much of it, from state or federal projects. Water tables are falling with 64% of wells at below-normal water levels. About 430 wells have gone dry in Madera County so far this year.

Title: Drought, wildfire concerns led some cities to forego the fireworks this year
Description:

Demand for fireworks was almost nonexistent during the pandemic, but suddenly demand for them is high, leading to problems with overseas shipping, transportation in the U.S., rising insurance costs and labor shortages, which have all contributed to the canceled displays.
•	Phoenix canceled its three major displays because they couldn’t get professional-grade fireworks
•	Flagstaff, AZ will have a new laser light show instead of fireworks
•	The Lake Don Pedro display in California was canceled due to drought and the low lake level
•	Wildfire concerns caused cancellations in Lompoc, CA and Castle Rock, CO
•	Albuquerque and Santa Fe in NM are go for fireworks, despite the immense wildfire activity that the state has seen this year

Description:

Description:

An estimated 14,000 trees died in Los Angeles’ city parks alone, due to watering restrictions during the previous drought. City officials have underscored the importance of watering trees amid the current drought.

Title: Water users in San Jose, California could be fined up to $10,000 for water waste
Description:

Residents who observe water waste can contact the district to report it. A first violation will result in a letter being sent. A fine may follow a third violation, but violators would have to egregiously overwater and blatantly refuse to obey the water rules to be fined $10,000.
The water district, however, only has three water cops for the entire county to enforce water rules.
The district’s 10 reservoirs in Santa Clara County are just 23% full.

Title: Mandatory water conservation for Marin Municipal Water District in California
Description:
The Marin Municipal Water District board unanimously approved mandatory restrictions for its 195,000 customers in south and central Marin County which would take effect on May 1.  The goal was to curb overall districtwide water use by 40%.  Certain non-essential water uses were prohibited, such as washing vehicles at home and power-washing, among other activities.  Additional irrigation restrictions will be considered in two weeks.
Mandatory restrictions are triggered when reservoir levels fall to 40,000 feet by April 1.  Reservoirs were slightly above 41,000 feet as of April 22.  Marin Water’s reservoir storage was 52%, whereas normal levels for this time of year are more than 90%.  Marin Water does not get water from the Sierra as other parts of California do.
NBC Bay Area (San Jose, Calif.), April 22, 2021

The Marin Municipal Water District proposed mandatory conservation rules for the first time since 1988 in response to historically low rainfall like that during the 1976-77 drought.  The proposed ordinance would allow outdoor watering one day per week starting May 1.  The district board of directors will vote on the ordinance on April 20.  
The North Marin Water District will consider similar mandatory conservation rules later in April. 
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), April 7, 2021

Description:
The Marin Municipal Water District board unanimously approved mandatory restrictions for its 195,000 customers in south and central Marin County which would take effect on May 1.  The goal was to curb overall districtwide water use by 40%.  Certain non-essential water uses were prohibited, such as washing vehicles at home and power-washing, among other activities.  Additional irrigation restrictions will be considered in two weeks.
Mandatory restrictions are triggered when reservoir levels fall to 40,000 feet by April 1.  Reservoirs were slightly above 41,000 feet as of April 22.  Marin Water’s reservoir storage was 52%, whereas normal levels for this time of year are more than 90%.  Marin Water does not get water from the Sierra as other parts of California do.
NBC Bay Area (San Jose, Calif.), April 22, 2021

The Marin Municipal Water District proposed mandatory conservation rules for the first time since 1988 in response to historically low rainfall like that during the 1976-77 drought.  The proposed ordinance would allow outdoor watering one day per week starting May 1.  The district board of directors will vote on the ordinance on April 20.  
The North Marin Water District will consider similar mandatory conservation rules later in April. 
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), April 7, 2021

Title: Some drought rules made permanent in Marin, California
Description:
The Marin Municipal Water District Board of Directors voted unanimously on May 3 to continue limiting sprinkler use to two days per week instead of the three days allowed before drought restrictions were adopted in 2021. Drip irrigation will be allowed three days a week. All pool owners in the district must also have a pool cover. A few rules were rescinded also, concerning car washing at home and the ban on landscape planting.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), May 4, 2022

Title: Fewer outdoor watering days in Santa Clara, California
Description:
Santa Clara residents may water landscaping only two days per week, instead of three. The city will also expand public information and increase water waste patrols. 
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), April 21, 2022

Title: Stage 2 water conservation in Visalia, California
Description:
The Visalia City Council authorized Stage 2 of the city’s Water Conservation Ordinance. Residents may only use sprinkler systems twice per week from March through November. 
Visalia Times Delta (Calif.), April 5, 2022

Title: More mosquitoes infected with West Nile Virus in Pasadena, California
Description:
Drought has persisted in the San Gabriel Valley for years. Research suggests a relationship between drought intensity and the percentage of infected West Nile mosquitoes. 
Data from the San Gabriel Valley Mosquito and Vector Control District revealed that a total of 17 mosquito samples from San Gabriel Valley tested positive for WNV in 2019. The number of positive samples in 2020 increased to 53, and in 2021, 190 samples tested positive.
The virus can be found in several types of birds and is transmitted by the bites of mosquitoes that feed on infected birds, but human cases have not risen over the same time period.
Pasadena Now (Calif.), April 4, 2022

Title: Stage 2 drought emergency in Solvang, California
Description:
Solvang’s Stage Two Drought Resolution remains in effect until the city council decides to lift it. In the meantime, the drought continues to be serious, and water conservation is needed.
Noozhawk.com (Santa Barbara, Calif.), Oct 26, 2021

Solvang City Council members declared a Stage 2 drought on Aug. 23, and mandatory water restrictions will take effect after the September meter reading. Those who do not conserve will be fined.
A Stage 1 drought emergency began in April, but rather than falling, water use rose 15% in May, 7% in June and 10% in July.  As water supplies dropped, water use increased 22%.  As of Aug. 23, Cachuma Lake was below 52% capacity.
Lompoc Record (Calif.), Sept 22, 2021

Title: Stage 4 drought in Mendocino, California
Description:
The Mendocino City Community Services District Board of Directors declared a Stage 4 Drought effective immediately, which requires a 40% reduction in water use.
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), March 31, 2022

Title: Water emergency, mandatory restrictions for Half Moon Bay, California
Description:
Half Moon Bay’s main water provider, the Coastside County Water District, declared a water shortage emergency on March 24, prompting a move to the second stage of the Water Shortage Contingency Plan. The aim is to reduce water sales by 17 percent, mostly through curbing outdoor irrigation by 50 percent from 2020 levels. All residential customers are asked to keep their water use to 50 gallons or less daily.
Some mandatory restrictions took effect also. People are not to use water to clean pavement, except for health or safety reasons, or use a hose without a shut-off nozzle.
Half Moon Bay Review (Calif.), March 30, 2022

Title: California irrigation districts offer smaller water allocations
Description:
The Turlock Irrigation District (TID) is allowing its farmers about 60% of normal supplies amid a third year of drought. The irrigation season began on March 29 with an allotment of 27 inches through the season which will end on Oct. 12.
The Modesto Irrigation District, which also draws water from Don Pedro Reservoir like the TID, has designated 30 inches for its irrigators. 
The Merced Irrigation District will provide just 1.1 acre-feet of water, or about 13 inches, from the Merced River.
The Modesto Bee (Calif.), March 28, 2022

Description:

Title: Water conservation led to increase in water rates in Pleasanton, California
Description:
Stricter water conservation in Pleasanton starting in October 2021 has resulted in a usage reduction of 18%-22% and cost the water utility an estimated $3.2 million in revenue, which has drawn down the city’s financial reserves and risked its ability to finance an upcoming fix for Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) chemicals. 
Starting May 1, the city will increase its water rates and charge Stage Two Water Drought Rates, tacking on $0.65 per 100 cubic feet of water to single-family home water bills. Commercial and multi-family homes will see an added $0.62 per 100 cubic feet charge, and irrigation water users will see an added $0.65 per 100 cubic feet charge.
This is the first time that Pleasanton’s drought rate activation has been used. Charges for May-June water use will appear on the July bill.
Livermore Independent (Calif.), March 24, 2022

Title: Metropolitan Water District of Southern California declared a drought emergency
Description:
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California declared a drought emergency on Nov. 9 and told local water suppliers to immediately use less water from the State Water Project. People should intensify water conservations efforts, as must the six water agencies that draw heavily or exclusively from the depleted State Water Project. 
California’s last two water years, which end on Sept. 30, were the driest two-year period in more than 100 years. This year water agencies received just 5% of full allocations from the SWP. In December, state water officials are expected to announce an initial 0% allocation for 2022.
Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Nov 9, 2021

The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California’s drought emergency declaration follows Gov. Gavin Newsom’s Oct. 19 proclamation of a statewide drought emergency.
In July, Gov. Newsom urged Californians to conserve 15% of water compared to last year’s use, but conservation amounted to 5% in August.
KNBC-TV NBC 4 Los Angeles (Calif.), Nov 9, 2021

Title: Monrovia, California water customers conserve 10% or pay fine
Description:
Residents of Monrovia must reduce their water use by 10% or pay fines averaging $10 per month or more for excessive water use. 
The city council voted on this plan in December after California Gov. Gavin Newsom urged a voluntary 15% reduction amid the drought. The city decided on a 10% reduction for all residents, feeling that the dire drought justified such aggressive action.
CBS Los Angeles (Calif.), March 14, 2022

Title: Water conservation of 15% requested in Sacramento, California
Description:
Sacramento officials request that water users voluntarily conserve 15% since measurable rain last fell on Jan. 7, over two months ago. The city also offers rebates of up to $1,500 for homeowners who replace their grass.
KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), March 10, 2022

Description:
Shasta Lake was one of the many cities that learned that allocations from the Central Valley Project would be limited in 2022 and asked its customers to reduce water use and outdoor watering to conserve water.

Title: Drought emergency in Santa Clara, California
Description:
The driest January on record leaves Santa Clara in a drought emergency. The Santa Clara Valley Water District anticipates needing to buy costly emergency water so the city has enough for the year. More conservation is needed.
The Silicon Valley Voice (Santa Clara, Calif.), Feb 17, 2022

Title: Emerald Fire in California
Description:
A wildfire sparked in Orange County near Emerald Bay in the early morning hours of Feb. 10. Gusty Santa Ana winds drove the flames, causing several hundred residents to evacuate as 145 acres burned. No homes were lost.
This is the second winter wildfire in the Golden State after a blaze burned in January near Big Sur.
Associated Press News (New York), Feb 10, 2022

Title: Brook trout stocked in urban, suburban park ponds around Sacramento, California
Description:
The California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) will provide trout anglers in the greater Sacramento area with an unprecedented fishing opportunity this winter: the chance to catch brook trout from a half-dozen urban and suburban park ponds and lakes that are part of CDFW’s Fishing in the City program.
California Department of Fish and Wildlife (Sacramento, Calif.), Jan 12, 2022

Title: Higher water rates for excessive water use in Los Angeles, California
Description:
Water rates for Los Angeles’ heaviest water users rose up to $3.60 per 748 gallons of water, effective Jan. 1. the Los Angeles Department Board of Water and Power Commissioners approved the rate changes in September 2021 to cover increasing water supply costs from customers who use a lot of water.
Spectrum News 1 (El Segundo, Calif.), Jan 5, 2022

Title: Preparation for continued drought in Marin County, California with plans for pipeline across bridge
Description:
Thanks to abundant rainfall refilling reservoirs, the Marin Municipal Water District was no longer in a big rush to construct the $100 million pipeline across the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge which would provide more water for MMWD customers if reservoirs were to run dry. The region received more than 200% of its normal rainfall from October through December, and the district’s seven reservoirs refilled from 32% of capacity in mid-October to nearly 93% in early January 2022.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Jan 5, 2022

After a number of atmospheric rivers that brought tremendous rain to Marin County, the reservoirs have refilled from 32% to 74% of capacity on Dec. 17 and water officials were reconsidering some drought restrictions and penalties that were introduced earlier.  
Since July, the Marin Municipal Water District has received about 34 inches of rain, or about 240% of normal to date. 
The utility continues to plan for water projects like the $100 million pipeline across the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge that would pump in water purchased from Yuba County. The district began planning the pipeline when it appeared that its local reservoir supplies could be depleted as soon as July 2022.
The San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec 19, 2021

More than 17 inches of desperately needed rain fell at Lake Lagunitas reservoir Oct. 18-25. The 17+ inches represents about a third of the 52 inches typically received in a year. Water supplies in the district’s seven reservoirs in the Mount Tamalpais watershed rose from 32% to 43% of total capacity, with the total storage increasing from about 25,772 acre-feet on Oct. 18 to 34,535 acre-feet on Oct. 25.
While the rain is beneficial, the Marin Municipal Water District is still planning to build the 8-mile pipeline across the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge to bring in additional water.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Oct 25, 2021

The Marin Municipal Water District was taking steps toward constructing an emergency water pipeline if the coming winter is dry like the last, to avoid running out of water next summer.  A consulting firm was seeking out potential water rights holders in the Central Valley that might be willing to sell their allotments.  
In the meantime, it is hoped that conservation efforts will continue to improve so the pipeline and temporary desalination plant can remain unused backup plans.  While conservation of 40% has been requested, residents conserved about 19% recently.  
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), June 23, 2021

The potential for water shortages in Marin County was so high that the Marin Municipal Water District was talking with East Bay officials about building a pipeline across the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge to bring water into the county if the upcoming winter shapes up to be as dry as the past two.  The emergency pipeline was once used during the 1976-77 drought.  A temporary desalination plant was another of several options under consideration to boost water supplies if the drought were to continue into a third year.  Marin only received 20 inches of rain during the winter, less than fell during the 1976-77 drought and the second least amount in the 143 years that records have been kept.  
The MMWD approved mandatory water restrictions on April 20 and could tighten restrictions further for its 190,000 customers in central and southern Marin.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), April 27, 2021

Title: California's Lake Mendocino becoming alarmingly low
Description:
Although water customers were urged to curb their water use by 50%, Lake Mendocino was still at less than 20% of capacity and has no significant backup supply. The reservoir needs decent precipitation through the winter to have enough to meet demand next summer and fall. Tens of thousands of people depend on the lake.
In addition, a faulty electric transformer for the Potter Valley Project means less water flowing into Lake Mendocino and typically provides about 30% of the lake’s inflow. Sedimentation may have reduced the amount of water that the lake holds so that there is less water there than expected.
Grape growers were denied district water since April, and yield losses were 20% to 60% for many growers.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), Nov 12, 2021

Title: Slow start to winter led to a snow drought in the Western U.S.
Description:
Snowpack in the Western U.S. was lagging as warm temperatures and lack of precipitation contributed to the snow drought.
Denver broke its 87-year-old measurable snowfall record originally set on Nov. 21, 1934 and is approaching an 1887 record of 235 consecutive days without snow.
This is only the second time since 1976 that Salt Lake City has gone snowless through November. Several ski resorts, including Powder Mountain and Snowbasin near Ogden, have not yet opened due to the absence of snow.
In western Wyoming, Jackson Hole Mountain Resort opened on Thanksgiving, thanks to manmade snow on a small number of low-elevation runs and in an area for children and other inexperienced skiers. The upper mountain will open once natural snow falls.
Most ski resorts in the Rockies are eagerly awaiting snow to open. To be on the safe side, Breckenridge will hold its annual festival in honor of Ullr, the Norse God of Snow and the Patron Saint of Skiers. The four-day event will begin on Dec. 9.

Title: Initial allocation of 0% for California's State Water Project customers
Description:
California cities and farms should not expect to receive water from California’s State Water Project (SWP) in 2022, announced the state officials. This is the earliest date that the Department of Water Resources has announced a 0% water allocation, indicative of just how serious drought conditions are as reservoirs plunge to record low levels. Mandatory restrictions will be put in place if the winter dryness persists. 
Twenty-nine water districts in California typically request water from the SWP. Partial allocations are delivered, depending on snowfall and reservoir storage. The initial allocation in December 2020 was 10% and was reduced to 5% in March 2021. 
Seven districts that requested water will get some of the roughly 340,000 acre-feet to be divvied this year among the districts for critical health and safety needs, like fire suppression. The Metropolitan Water District in Southern California, providing water for about 19 million people, will receive some water. The system was intended to deliver more than 4.2 million acre-feet.
Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a statewide drought emergency in October and urged water conservation.
Associated Press News (New York), Dec 1, 2021

Title: Mandatory water conservation in Santa Rosa, California
Description:
The Santa Rosa city council voted to make voluntary conservation mandatory as Russian River wholesale water allocations were cut and Sonoma County declared a local drought emergency.  Water conservation of 20% over last year’s use is the goal.
Other North Bay communities with mandatory water restrictions include Petaluma, Sonoma, Rohnert Park, Healdsburg and Cloverdale.
KTVU (San Francisco, Calif.), June 30, 2021

Title: Fallow land; expensive water in Fresno County, California
Description:
A Fresno County farmer left one-third of his 6,000 acres fallow because water was so scarce and relied upon emergency sources for a reduced crop.  The supplemental water cost him $2,000 per acre-foot, compared to normal water prices of $200 to $250 per acre-foot.
“If there is no water, there is no work, no money.”
Times of San Diego (Calif.), June 26, 2021

Title: Earthy taste to water in Sacramento, California
Description:
Drought has altered the taste and smell of Sacramento’s water as the concentration of geosmin increased.  The water is safe to drink.  Officials suggested either adding lemon or refrigerating the water to lessen the unpleasant taste and smell.  The water usually gets a little funky in late summer or early fall when water levels are low.
CNN US (N.Y.), June 22, 2021

Title: Voluntary water conservation urged in Healdsburg, California
Description:
Healdsburg residents were urged to voluntarily conserve water as precipitation was 40% of normal through Jan. 19.  Lake Mendocino was at 45.1% of its targeted water supply curve as of Feb. 16.
Healdsburg, in conjunction with Sonoma-Marin Saving Water Partnership, will be launching a social media campaign with tips on reducing water waste. Healdsburg residents will also receive a water conservation mailer with their next utility bill.
The Healdsburg Tribune (Calif.), Feb. 23, 2021

Title: Stricter fire restrictions at Lake Tahoe, California/Nevada
Description:
Drought and heat led to increased fire restrictions in the Lake Tahoe Basin through November.  Fire-related activities were prohibited at developed recreation sites and in the backcountry.
Reno Gazette Journal (Nev.), June 17, 2021

The North Tahoe and Meeks Bay Fire Protection Districts announced a suspension of all solid fuel fires, including wood campfires and charcoal grills, for the summer as the forest was unusually dry.  Campfires and charcoal barbecues were still permitted in designated fire pits in campgrounds.
“Timber vegetation [is] already at summer dryness levels, and above normal fire activity is projected in the Sierra and Tahoe regions this summer and likely into the fall,” according to the North Tahoe Fire Protection District fire chief.
SFGate (San Francisco, Calif.), June 3, 2021

All open burning and recreational fires were prohibited in the Lake Tahoe basin.  The Amador/El Dorado Unit of Cal Fire suspended burn permits on May 10 for the season and on May 24, the Nevada Yuba Placer Unit did the same, leading to full suspension of residential burn permits.  
Tahoe Daily Tribune (South Lake Tahoe, Calif.), May 29, 2021

Title: Request for water conservation of 20% in Sonoma, California
Description:
The Valley of the Moon District and the city of Sonoma were requesting that the public reduce their water use by 20%.  Local aquifers were low, and so were reservoirs on the Russian River after two dry years in the area. 
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 17, 2021

Title: Drought emergency in Healdsburg, California
Description:
Healdsburg officials declared a drought emergency on June 11, mandating that sprinklers and drip irrigation systems be turned off.  Meanwhile, the state ordered Healdsburg to slash its water use by 40%.  Residents were limited to using no more than 74 gallons daily.  
Water customers were first asked to curb use by 20% on May 3, but the water situation has deteriorated as Lake Mendocino continued to drop.
Without additional rain, the possibility exists that water may not be able to be released from the reservoir in the fall, leaving Healdsburg without water.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 16, 2021

Title: Dozens of dry wells near Orland, California
Description:
Dozens of wells in the Orland area went dry, forcing some to haul water.  Many people were reluctant to turn on their pumps for fear of them burning out.
KHSL CBS 12 (Chico, Calif.), May 31, 2021

Title: Many dead trees in East Bay regional parks in California
Description:
Lack of rain was thought to be responsible for the many dead or dying trees in East Bay Regional Parks.  Fire officials feared that the dead trees could easily fuel fires which could destroy homes.  The affected trees were acacia, eucalyptus, Monterey pines, manzanitas and others.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), May 25, 2021

Title: Water districts near Sacramento, California urged to rely on groundwater more
Description:
As the level of Folsom Lake fell to one of its lowest points ever, the Sacramento Regional Water Authority was urging its 20 water districts in the Sacramento area to rely more on groundwater than surface water to reduce reliance on Folsom Lake and the Lower American River.
CBS Sacramento (Calif.), May 14, 2021

Title: Phase II water emergency in St. Helena, California
Description:
St. Helena remained in a Phase II water emergency, and water rationing was in effect. 
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 11, 2021

St. Helena officials adopted a sliding scale of fines, effective June 1 for water customers who exceed their allowed consumption during the emergency.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 5, 2021

New penalties will be imposed on St. Helena water customers who exceed their rations beginning May 1 as the Phase II water emergency continued.  The penalties must be approved at an upcoming April 13 council meeting. The city allocates 65 gallons per person daily, plus 2,500 gallons per month for outdoor use.  
St. Helena’s Bell Canyon Reservoir is at 42% of capacity.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 24, 2021

The Phase II water emergency remained in effect for St. Helena.  Bell Canyon Reservoir had an elevation of 400.11 feet, or about 40% of capacity.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 10, 2021

Drought and increased water demand for firefighting led St. Helena authorities to declare a Phase II water emergency and order mandatory rationing.  Bell Canyon Reservoir was at 38.8 percent of capacity after a year of meager rainfall yielding just 20 inches.  An unknown amount of water was also used to fight the LNU Lightning Complex and Glass fires.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct 28, 2020

Title: Water conservation encouraged in Napa, California
Description:
The Napa city council approved a moderate water shortage declaration on May 4, bringing back restrictions on water use that were last in effect during the mid-2010s.  Restrictions on outdoor watering were in place with the goal of reducing water use by 15%.  Council members also voted in favor of purchasing up to 1,400 acre-feet of water using $640,000 from a city reserve fund.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 5, 2021

Napa residents were urged to conserve water as Lake Hennessey, the city’s primary water source, was at 68% of capacity, containing 21,000 acre-feet of water.  
KRON 4 (San Francisco), April 24, 2021

Title: Emergency declaration in Yountville, California
Description:
Yountville approved an emergency declaration on May 4, due to a forecast 20% decrease in allotment from Rector Reservoir.  Restrictions on outdoor irrigation, vehicle and pavement washing and fountain use were enacted, similar to Napa’s restrictions.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 5, 2021

Title: Water restrictions in Calistoga, California
Description:
Calistoga banned irrigation using municipal water on certain days and restricted vehicle washing, pool filling and other activities.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 5, 2021

Title: Water supplies tight in American Canyon, California
Description:
American Canyon used 2,884 acre-feet in 2020 and presently only has 1,852 acre-feet for 2021.  Consequently, the city is 1,032 acre-feet short of water this year and will use Vallejo emergency permit water and supplies from state water transfer programs, leaving no carry-over water for 2022.
American Canyon gets its water from the State Water Project and has no local reservoir.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 7, 2021

Title: Voluntary 20% water conservation requested in Petaluma, California
Description:
Petaluma was in the first stage of its four-tiered water shortage contingency plan, urging a voluntary 20% reduction in water use.  Residents ought to expect more severe restrictions in the near future.
Petaluma360 & Petaluma Argus Courier (Calif.), May 7, 2021

Title: Stage 3 drought in Mendocino, California
Description:
The Mendocino City Community Services District declared a Stage 3 drought on March 29.  The district recorded about 20.5 inches of rain year to date for the second lowest total in the last century.  Water allotments will be reduced by 20%.  The district may consider a Stage 4 drought declaration at its April 26 meeting.  
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), March 30, 2021

Title: Stage 4 drought in Mendocino, California
Description:
Mendocino remains at Stage 4 drought status until at least Dec. 20 when the topic will be revisited at the next Mendocino City Community Services District meeting.
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), Oct 28, 2021

A Stage 4 drought was declared by the Mendocino City Community Services District board, requiring a 40% mandatory reduction in water use.  During dry years in the Mendocino area, it is common for residents to refill water tanks with water purchased from surrounding communities. 
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), May 5, 2021

Title: Water conservation of 15% urged in Santa Margarita, California
Description:
Meager rainfall has cut into water supplies for Santa Margarita where water customers were urged to curb their water use by 15%.  
Santa Margarita was also under a water alert that was triggered when groundwater fell below a certain threshold or when the three-year cumulative rainfall total was less than 84 inches, both of which were true.  
KSBY-TV San Luis Obispo (Calif.), May 3, 2021

Title: Water users in Solvang, California urged to conserve 15%
Description:
Meager rainfall has cut into water supplies for Solvang, where water customers were urged to curb their water use by 15%. 
The Solvang city council voted to impose restrictions in April and also to spend $400,000 on supplemental water.  
KSBY-TV San Luis Obispo (Calif.), May 3, 2021

Title: Increased water conservation in Santa Rosa, California
Description:
Santa Rosans conserved more water since the start of the year when the water provider conveyed the need for conservation with the public cutting their use by 15%, compared to the first three months of 2020.
Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 26, 2021

Title: Water conservation kits being distributed in Lompoc, California
Description:
Water conservation kits were being distributed at Lompoc city libraries through the end of May.  The kits contain low-flow showerheads for adults or coloring books for young students, planting supplies and conservation goodies for middle and high school students.
KVEC (San Luis Obispo, Calif.), April 28, 2021

Title: Water conservation in San Francisco, California
Description:
The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission urged its irrigation customers and city departments to voluntarily conserve 10% of typical water use.  The SFPUC’s reservoirs were at 76.8% of maximum storage capacity, which is slightly below the historical average of 81% for this time of year.
San Franciscans use an average of 42 gallons of water daily, one of the lowest rates in California.
KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), April 29, 2021

Title: Shallow wells in California's San Joaquin Valley at risk of running dry
Description:
Shallow wells in the San Joaquin Valley may be at risk of running dry this summer as California endures a second dry year, leading farmers to rely more heavily on pumping groundwater.  A Riverdale well driller in Fresno County reported that he received 15 to 20 calls before noon on April 16 from residents in Fresno and Kings counties who needed pumps lowered or a new well drilled.  The well driller and others anticipate that this second consecutive dry year will cause many dry shallow wells in the valley and crisis for homeowners who cannot afford the cost of a new well.  
During the 2012-2016 drought, more than 2,000 residential wells in the Valley went dry.
The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 22, 2021

Title: Switch to groundwater in Santa Maria, California
Description:
The City of Santa Maria has switched to groundwater, due to drought, and will continue using groundwater through May.  Groundwater will also be used again in November and December.  Water quality may change somewhat, due to the increased hardness and mineral content.  The city’s website states that its other water source is imported State Water. 
KEYT-TV ABC 3 Santa Barbara (Calif.), April 20, 2021

Title: Drought reduced number of potholes in Los Angeles, California
Description:
Pothole service requests in Los Angeles were down 25%, per the Los Angeles Bureau of Street Services.  Just 14,000 potholes were reported in the first nine months of the fiscal year, compared to 18,400 the previous period.  The decrease is partly due to drought as there was less water to damage roads.
Spectrum News 1 (El Segundo, Calif.), April 19, 2021

Title: Stage one drought in Solvang, California
Description:
Solvang city council members unanimously declared a stage one drought condition on April 12 as the California State Water Resources Control Board lowered the city’s allocation of water.  A voluntary 15% reduction in water use was urged and some water restrictions were mandated.  The city may buy up to $400,000 in supplemental water.  
Santa Ynez Valley News (Calif.), April 13, 2021

Title: Less water for the South San Joaquin Irrigation District in California
Description:
The South San Joaquin Irrigation District learned that runoff from the Stanislaus River watershed would be 20,000 to 40,000 acre-feet of water less than the previous estimate.  The SSJID might not receive more than 225,000 acre-feet, compared to 2020 when the district received 249,000 acre-feet, as inflow to the Melones Dam was expected to be far below normal.  Plans were scrapped to release up to 100,000 acre feet to boost the spring pulse flow for threatened fish in the Stanislaus River and then sell that water to west side farmers that are without state water this year for lack of water.
Escalon Times (Oakdale, Calif.), April 13, 2021

Title: Disruption in agricultural water supply to Santa Rosa Junior College in Sonoma County, California
Description:
The Sonoma County Water Agency cutting off Santa Rosa Junior College’s secondary agricultural water supply to its farm from April to October, due to the drought, according to the Dean of Agriculture. Its primary supply comes from the city of Windsor.
North Bay Business Journal (Santa Rosa, Calif.), April 14, 2021

Title: Drought among factors leading to fireworks ban in Sebastopol, California
Description:
Sebastopol’s City Council aimed to end the sale and use of fireworks within city limits and directed city staff to draft an ordinance banning fireworks.  Reasons for the impending permanent ban were worsening drought, the potential for fires and concerns about being one of only a few cities in Sonoma County to allow fireworks.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 7, 2021

Title: Hay farmer irrigating early, stressed about meager water supplies in Tulelake, California
Description:
A hay farmer in Tulelake, California began watering his fields earlier than ever this year, but runoff in Klamath Lake was late.  Upper Klamath Lake levels were about a foot lower than normal for this time of year, and inflows to Upper Klamath Lake were the lowest on record.
The hay farmer stated, "I'm frightened, scared to death actually. You know, I'm a younger guy starting out farming and I've got mortgages to pay, pay the landowners and without being able to produce a crop, and this year is looking to be devastating.  I mean we're looking at zeroing fields out."
Klamath County received a drought declaration from Gov. Brown last week as water supplies were unusually low.
KTVL - Channel 10 News (Medford, Ore.), April 8, 2021

Title: California's Marin Municipal Water District urging voluntary conservation
Description:
For the first time since 2013, the Marin Municipal Water District urged customers to voluntarily curb their water use as rainfall was low like during the 1976-77 drought.  No specific conservation target was set forth, but a 22 percent voluntary reduction would significantly help MMWD’s water storage outlook.  As of Feb. 15, reservoirs held 66 percent of average capacity.
A 20 percent drop in water use would mean an estimated loss of $8 million in revenue for MMWD.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 18, 2021

Title: Stage 2 drought restrictions in Mendocino, California
Description:
The Stage 2 drought designation was extended for Mendocino at the monthly Mendocino City Community Services District meeting.  A voluntary water use reduction of 15% was encouraged.  Through Feb. 17, the precipitation total for the water year was about 47% of normal.  
The average depth of Mendocino’s water table as of February 16 measured at 19.61 feet, compared to 14.56 feet in February 2020. The depth is the average distance from the surface of the earth to the water from 24 monitoring wells. A lower number indicates more water.
The water supply situation will be reviewed on March 31.
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2021

The Mendocino City Community Services District voted to continue the Stage 2 drought status and will revisit the possibility of increasing water use restrictions at a Feb. 22 meeting.  In Stage 2 drought, residents are requested to voluntarily curb water use by 15 percent.
As of Jan. 20, the rain year totals were about 22 percent of average.
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), Jan. 26, 2021

Title: Water rationing plan approved in Bolinas, California
Description:
The Bolinas Community Public Utility approved a water rationing plan that would take effect when the district’s customers use more than 76,000 gallons per day on average for seven consecutive days.  When the plan is triggered, mandatory rationing of 125 gallons per household will be enforced or the household’s water will be shut off after being warned twice to curb water use.
Marin County relies primarily on rainwater for water supplies.  Without continued conservation, the district projects it could deplete the 8.8 million gallons of water at its two reservoirs as soon as July if no significant rainfall occurs, according to the district’s general manager.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 26, 2021

Title: Updated water allocation of 5% for California's State Water Project
Description:
The California Department of Water Resources updated its initial water allocation for the 2021 water year to 5% of requested supplies, down from 10% as announced in December 2020.  The allocation will be finalized by May.  The State Water Project serves more than 27 million people and provides irrigation for about 750,000 acres of farmland, mostly in the San Joaquin Valley.
YubaNet (Calif.), March 23, 2021

The California Department of Water Resources announced the initial water allocation of 10 percent for the State Water Project.  While the initial allocation was low, the allocation last year was also 10 percent, but was increased to 20 percent in May 2020. 
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Dec. 1 2020

Title: Water conservation urged for customers of the Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description:
Customers of the Santa Clara Valley Water District were urged to increase their conservation efforts, but no water restrictions were mandated just yet.  Other large water agencies in the Bay Area were similarly asking customers to conserve, but were not yet taking a tougher approach.  The SCVWD, serving 2 million people in the Silicon Valley, will make the decision on future restrictions by May and will be seeking to purchase water from other parts of the state to bolster its supplies.  
The district’s 10 reservoirs were 16% full on March 16. The Sierra Nevada snowpack was 61% of normal. Most Bay Area cities received only about 40% of the historic average rainfall this winter.
The SCVWD’s largest reservoir, Anderson Reservoir, was drained last year over federal regulators’ concerns that the dam could collapse if a major earthquake occurred. 
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), March 17, 2021

Title: Emergency water conservation rules for customers in Novato, California
Description:
The North Marin Water District approved emergency conservation rules for Novato residents and businesses as rainfall remained scarce.  Just about 8 inches of rain fell at the Stafford Lake reservoir since July, a record low since record-keeping began in 1916.  The ordinance that the board adopted will allow the district the ability to enact stricter measures more quickly if needed in the near future, once updates are received from the Sonoma County Water Agency in about one month.  
In the meantime, water users were urged to continue conserving water.  The district serves about 61,000 residents in the greater Novato area.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), March 17, 2021

Title: Water shortage emergency a possibility for North Marin Water District in California
Description:
The North Marin Water District was considering a water shortage emergency as Stafford Lake was at 30% of capacity.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), March 2, 2021

The North Marin Water District is considering whether a voluntary or mandatory water conservation order was needed in Novato, due to historically low rainfall.  The district received just 7 inches, the least amount since record keeping began in 1916.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.)
Feb. 27, 2021

Title: Water conservation mandate for North Marin Water District in California
Description:
The North Marin Water District, serving Novato, implemented a 25 percent water conservation mandate on July 1, due to the water shortage emergency declared in early May when customers were asked to voluntarily reduce water use by 15 percent in May and June.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), July 16, 2020

Title: Russian River water pumped into Stafford Lake to bolster supplies as California reservoir remained low
Description:
The North Marin Water District was pumping 600 acre-feet of water from the Russian River into Stafford Lake to increase supplies for the summer, a strategy that was employed by the district during the 1976-77 drought.  The 600 acre-feet amounts to about 30% of the normal demand of the reservoir over the summer.  The district general manager stated that the district intended to fill the lake from 1,300 acre-feet, or 30% capacity, to at least 50% capacity, which will cost about $221,000. 
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2021

Title: Plans to resume tree planting in Fullerton, California
Description:
Drought and budget constraints made the city of Fullerton taper off its tree plantings in 2017, but a new $377,00 Cal Fire grant and $180,000 of city money will allow tree plantings to resume.
Orange County Register (Calif.), Jan. 29, 2021

Title: Low rainfall has Marin County, California water districts leaning toward mandatory restrictions
Description:
Two water districts in Marin County were considering mandatory water restrictions amid a winter of abnormally low rainfall and the possible return to drought.  The community of Bolinas was also considering mandatory water rationing that could take effect as soon as March 1.  
Much of Marin’s water supply comes from reservoirs replenished with rainwater, but most water agencies have reported less than half of normal rainfall.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2021

The community of Bolinas is on the cusp of mandating water rationing, allowing 150 gallons of water per day.  Bolinas depends on the Arroyo Honda Creek where water levels were far below average.  
North Marin Water’s Stafford reservoir is at 29 percent of capacity, while the district’s seven lakes and reservoirs averaged 57 percent of capacity.  
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2021

Title: Less water flowing into water treatment plant in Santa Rosa, California
Description:
Less water was flowing into Santa Rosa’s water treatment plant where storage ponds typically hold 600 million gallons, but currently held 400 million gallons.  The reduction in stored water means that there will be less recycled water available for agricultural users this spring unless more rain falls.
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Residents asked to water trees in Piedmont, California
Description:
Residents of Piedmont were urged to water their trees a few times a week as the trees were stressed by a second year of drought.  
East Bay Times (Walnut Creek, Calif.), Jan. 13, 2021

Title: Phase I water emergency in St. Helena, California
Description:
The St. Helena City Council declared a Phase I water emergency on June 23.  Since July 2019, the city received just 20 inches of rain, leaving Bell Canyon Reservoir at 60 percent of capacity and expected to fall to 33 to 40 percent in November.  The reservoir is one of three water sources for St. Helena. 
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), June 27, 2020

Title: Drought, heat affected grape growth in Napa County, California
Description:
A grape grower in Carneros reported vines struggling, due to dry soils, and reduced yields.  Chardonnay yields were down over 50 percent and Pinot Noir grapes were at least 15 percent below average.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Aug. 25, 2020

Title: Stage 1 water conservation in Visalia, California
Description:
The Visalia City Council met on July 20 and unanimously approved moving from Stage 1 to Stage 3 water conservation as the city’s groundwater level sank 7 feet since April.  
Visalia entered Stage 1 of its water ordinance in August 2017, and was in Stage 2 for the previous year and a half.  
Foothills Sun Gazette (Exeter, Calif.), July 29, 2020

Title: Water shortage emergency in Inverness, California
Description:
A water shortage emergency was declared in Inverness as dry weather depleted water supplies.  
Point Reyes Light (Point Reyes Station, Calif.), July 29, 2020

The Inverness Public Utility planned to declare a water shortage emergency on July 22, due to historic low rainfall in the watershed.  The district has no reservoirs and instead draws from stream flows from the Inverness Ridge to refill its storage tanks.  Although the area typically receives 15.5 inches of precipitation from February through June, only 6 inches fell.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), July 16, 2020

Title: Water conservation alert in Bolinas, California
Description:
The Bolinas Community Public Utility District issued a conservation alert on June 19 requesting a 20 to 30 percent reduction in water use.  The district has a moratorium on new connections to its system, due to a limited supply from Arroyo Hondo Creek and two emergency reservoirs.  Water rationing could be enacted as early as this summer.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), July 16, 2020

Title: Stage 4 drought for Mendocino,California
Description:
The stage 4 drought declared for Mendocino on June 29 continued with no change in conditions that prompted the current declaration.
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), July 28, 2020

The Mendocino City Community Services District Board declared a Stage 4 drought, cutting water allotments by 40 percent, as current rainfall was 50 percent of normal for the water year. No new groundwater extraction permits will be considered.  
The Mendocino Beacon (Calif.), July 7, 2020

Title: State Water Project allocation estimate of 20 percent for California water agencies
Description:
After a dry winter, the State Water Project increased its allocation to 20 percent following above normal precipitation in May.  The initial allocation in December 2019 was 10 percent, and the January estimate was increased to 15 percent.  The most recent allocation will likely be final for 2020.
East County Today (Antioch, Calif.), May 26, 2020

The State Water Project allocation for 2020 remained at 15 percent as of May 13.
Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), May 13, 2020

The California Department of Water Resource estimated a delivery allocation of 15 percent for the San Bernardino Valley Municipal Water District and other agencies which receive water from the State Water Project.  The SWP typically provides closer to 30 percent of the needed water, but snowpack in the Sierra Nevada was 70 percent of normal at the end of January.
Highland Community News (Calif.), Feb. 13, 2020

Title: Drought increased tree maintenance costs in Yorba Linda, California
Description:
The cost of maintaining the more than 32,000 trees in Yorba Linda exceeded the contracted amount by 25 percent as drought increased the number of trees requiring emergency removal and other work.  The three year contract that began in July 2016 estimated annual maintenance expenses at $681,500, but drought damage increased the costs by 35 percent to $920,476.  Three one-year contract extensions tacked on an additional $406,503 annually, increasing the total cost for six years of tree maintenance from $4.8 million to $6 million through June 2022. 
Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Jan. 30, 2020
